0: Prepare and process import and export documentation according to customs regulations, laws, or procedures.
Clear goods through customs and to their destinations for clients.
Pay, or arrange for payment of, taxes and duties on shipments.
Calculate duty and tariff payments owed on shipments.
Request or compile necessary import documentation, such as customs invoices, certificates of origin, and cargo-control documents.
Classify goods according to tariff coding system.
Stay abreast of changes in import or export laws or regulations by reading current literature, attending meetings or conferences, or conferring with colleagues.
Sign documents on behalf of clients, using powers of attorney.
Advise customers on import and export restrictions, tariff systems, insurance requirements, quotas, or other customs-related matters.
Post bonds for the products being imported or assist clients in obtaining bonds.
Quote duty and tax rates on goods to be imported, based on federal tariffs and excise taxes.
Arrange for transportation, warehousing, or product distribution of imported or exported products.
Monitor or trace the location of goods.
Confer with officials in various agencies to facilitate clearance of goods through customs and quarantine.
Inform importers and exporters of steps to reduce duties and taxes.
Obtain line releases for frequent shippers of low-risk commodities, high-volume entries, or multiple-container loads.
Provide advice on transportation options, types of carriers, or shipping routes.
Contract with freight forwarders for destination services.
Apply for tariff concessions or for duty drawbacks and other refunds.
Insure cargo against loss, damage, or pilferage.
Prepare papers for shippers to appeal duty charges.
1: Analyze training needs to develop new training programs or modify and improve existing programs.
Evaluate instructor performance and the effectiveness of training programs, providing recommendations for improvement.

Plan, develop, and provide training and staff development programs, using knowledge of the effectiveness of methods such as classroom training, demonstrations, on-the-job training, meetings, conferences, and workshops.
Confer with management and conduct surveys to identify training needs based on projected production processes, changes, and other factors.
Conduct orientation sessions and arrange on-the-job training for new hires.
Train instructors and supervisors in techniques and skills for training and dealing with employees.
Develop and organize training manuals, multimedia visual aids, and other educational materials.
Prepare training budget for department or organization.
Develop testing and evaluation procedures.
Conduct or arrange for ongoing technical training and personal development classes for staff members.
Review and evaluate training and apprenticeship programs for compliance with government standards.
2: Monitor and record food temperatures to ensure food safety.
Cook foodstuffs according to menus, special dietary or nutritional restrictions, or numbers of portions to be served.
Rotate and store food supplies.
Wash pots, pans, dishes, utensils, or other cooking equipment.
Apportion and serve food to facility residents, employees, or patrons.
Clean and inspect galley equipment, kitchen appliances, and work areas to ensure cleanliness and functional operation.
Clean, cut, and cook meat, fish, or poultry.
Direct activities of one or more workers who assist in preparing and serving meals.
Train new employees.
Take inventory of supplies and equipment.
Requisition food supplies, kitchen equipment, and appliances, based on estimates of future needs.
Bake breads, rolls, or other pastries.

0: Clear shipments through customs, ensuring compliance with regulations and laws governing imports/exports.
Prepare and submit necessary documentation to U.S. Customs and Border Protection (CBP) for clearance.
Conduct thorough inspections of shipment contents to verify accuracy of declared goods and values.
Negotiate with carriers, importers, and exporters to resolve issues related to shipments and compliance.
Collaborate with clients to gather required information for customs clearance and processing.
Maintain accurate records and databases of client transactions and correspondence.
Prepare and file necessary paperwork, including commercial invoices, certificates of origin, and bill of lading documents.
Coordinate with U.S. CBP officials to facilitate smooth clearance and reduce delays.
Stay up-to-date on changes in customs regulations, laws, and policies affecting import/export activities.
Develop and implement effective strategies for mitigating risks associated with customs compliance.
Communicate with clients regarding status of shipments, including any issues or concerns that may arise during processing.
Provide expert advice to clients on customs procedures, regulations, and requirements.
Prepare and submit Harmonized System (HS) codes, as required by CBP for accurate classification and valuation.
Manage and resolve claims related to lost or damaged shipments, ensuring fair compensation to clients.
Maintain knowledge of country-specific regulations, laws, and procedures relevant to customs clearance activities.
Develop and maintain strong relationships with carriers, suppliers, and other stakeholders to improve overall service delivery.
Monitor and track shipments in real-time, utilizing various technologies and systems to ensure seamless tracking and visibility.
Implement quality control measures to ensure compliance with established standards and regulations.
Provide training and support to clients on customs procedures, regulations, and best practices for continuous improvement.
Analyze data and metrics related to customs clearance activities, identifying trends and areas for process optimization.
Develop and maintain a comprehensive understanding of the client's overall import/export strategy, providing strategic advice as needed.
1: Design and implement training programs to enhance employees' skills and knowledge, in line with organizational goals and objectives.
Conduct needs assessments to identify skill gaps and develop targeted training interventions.
Develop and maintain curriculum plans, syllabi, and educational materials for various training programs.
Coordinate training logistics, including scheduling, budgeting, and resource allocation.
Collaborate with subject matter experts to design and deliver specialized training sessions on complex topics.
Evaluate the effectiveness of training programs through surveys, feedback forms, and performance metrics.
Create and disseminate training documentation, such as user manuals and policy guides.
Provide coaching and mentoring support to employees to promote knowledge retention and application of new skills.
Develop and manage training budgets, track expenses, and report on program ROI.
Conduct workshops, webinars, and online training sessions for internal or external stakeholders.
Stay up-to-date with industry trends, best practices, and emerging technologies to inform training programs and stay ahead of organizational needs.
2: Prepares and cooks food according to institutional nutrition standards and recipes.
Maintains a clean and sanitary kitchen environment, adhering to HACCP protocols.
Receives and stores incoming food inventory, rotating stock as needed.
Assists in menu planning and inventory management to minimize food waste.
Operates commercial cooking equipment, including ovens, stoves, and dishwashers.
Responsible for food safety and quality control, ensuring compliance with regulatory standards.
Participates in food preparation and presentation for special events and functions.
Manages inventory of ingredients and supplies, ordering as needed to maintain stock levels.
Coordinates with dietary staff to accommodate special dietary requests and restrictions.
Maintains accurate records of kitchen operations, including menu planning and food inventory.
Performs cleaning and maintenance tasks on kitchen equipment and facilities.
Ensures compliance with institutional food safety regulations and protocols.
